sen.j: 聖護院（しょうごいん）は京都府京都市左京区聖護院中町にある本山修験宗総本山の寺院。
sen.e: Shogo-in Temple is the head temple of the Buddhist Honzan Shugen Sect located in Shogo-in Nakamachi, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Shogo-in Temple is the head temple of the Buddhist Honzan Shugen Sect located in Shogo-in Nakamachi, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Shogo-in Temple is the head temple of the Buddhist Honzan Shugen Sect located in Shogo-in Nakamachi, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 同宗派設立以前は天台寺門宗に属した。
sen.e: Before the foundation of this sect, the temple belonged to the Tendaijimon Sect.
Before the foundation of this sect, the temple belonged to the Tendaijimon Sect.
Before the foundation of this sect, the temple belonged to the Tendaijimon Sect.

sen.j: 山号はなし。
sen.e: It does not have an honorific mountain prefix.
It does not have an honorific mountain prefix.
It does not have an honorific mountain prefix.

sen.j: 開基（創立者）は増誉、本尊は不動明王である。
sen.e: The temple was founded by Zoyo and its principal image is a statue of Fudo Myoo.
The temple was founded by Zoyo and its principal image is a statue of Fudo Myoo.
The temple was founded by Zoyo and its principal image is a statue of Fudo Myoo.

sen.j: 日本の修験道の中心寺院の1つ。
sen.e: It is one of the main temple of Japan's Shugendo (mountain asceticism) practice.
It is one of the main temple of Japan's Shugendo (mountain asceticism) practice.
It is one of the main temple of Japan's Shugendo (mountain asceticism) practice.

sen.j: 近世以降、修験道は江戸幕府の政策もあって「本山派」「当山派」の2つに分かれたが、聖護院はこのうちの本山派の中心寺院であった。
sen.e: During the early modern period, Shugendo was split into the "Honzan School" and "Tozan School" by the Edo Shogunate, and Shogo-in Temple was a central temple of the Honzan School.
During the early modern period, Shugendo was split into the "Honzan School" and "Tozan School" by the Edo Shogunate, and Shogo-in Temple was a central temple of the Honzan School.

During the early modern period, Shugendo was split into the 'Honzan school' and 'Tozan school' by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), and Shogo-in Temple was a central temple of the Honzan school.
sen.cmt: 「江戸幕府」の表記を修正、Honzan school, Tozan schoolとし、シングルクォーテーションに変更

sen.j: また、代々法親王（皇族男子で、出家後に親王宣下を受けた者）が入寺する門跡寺院として高い格式を誇った。
sen.e: The temple prospered as a "Monzeki Temple" served by successive Hoshinno (male members of the Imperial family who were granted the title Shinno after joining the Buddhist priesthood).
The temple prospered as a "Monzeki Temple" served by successive Hoshinno (male members of the Imperial family who were granted the title Shinno after joining the Buddhist priesthood).

The temple prospered as a "Monzeki Temple" served by successive Cloistered Imperial Princes (male members of the Imperial family who were granted the title Imperial Prince after joining the Buddhist priesthood).

sen.j: 江戸時代後期には2度にわたり仮皇居となったこともある。
sen.e: It also served as a temporary Imperial Palace twice during the Edo Period.
It also served as a temporary Imperial Palace twice during the Edo Period.
It also served as a temporary Imperial Palace twice during the Edo Period.

sen.j: 当寺の開基は園城寺の僧・増誉である。
sen.e: The founder of Shogo-in Temple was Zoyo, a monk from Enjo-ji Temple.
The founder of Shogo-in Temple was Zoyo, a monk from Enjo-ji Temple.
The founder of Shogo-in Temple was Zoyo, a monk from Onjo-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 園城寺(おんじょうじ)の読みの誤りを訂正

sen.j: 増誉は1090年（寛治4年）、白河天皇の熊野詣の先達（案内役）を務めた。
sen.e: Zoyo acted as Emperor Shirakawa's guide during his visit to Kumano in 1090.
Zoyo acted as Emperor Shirakawa's guide during his visit to Kumano in 1090.
Zoyo acted as Emperor Shirakawa's guide during his visit to Kumano in 1090.

sen.j: この功により増誉は初代の熊野三山検校（熊野三山霊場の統括責任者）に任じられ、役小角（修験道の開祖とされる伝説的人物）が創建したとされる常光寺を下賜された。
sen.e: As a reward, Zuyo was appointed Kumano Sanzan Kengyo (overseer of the three Kumano shrines) and was granted Joko-ji Temple, thought to have been founded by Enno Ozuno (a legendary character who believed to have founded Shugendo).

As a reward, Zuyo was appointed Kumano Sanzan Kengyo (overseer of the three Kumano shrines) and was granted Joko-ji Temple, thought to have been founded by Enno Ozuno (a legendary character who believed to have founded Shugendo).

As a reward, Zuyo was appointed Kumano Sanzan Kengyo (overseer of the three Kumano shrines) and was granted Joko-ji Temple, thought to have been founded by EN no Ozuno (a legendary character who believed to have founded Shugendo).
sen.cmt: 人名のため、Enno Ozuno→EN no Ozunoとしました。

sen.j: これが聖護院の創建である。
sen.e: This is the origin of Shogo-in Temple.
This is the origin of Shogo-in Temple.
This is the origin of Shogo-in Temple.

sen.j: 寺名は「聖体護持」の意である。
sen.e: The temple's name means "Seitai Goji" (protect the emperor).
The temple's name means "Seitai Goji" (protect the emperor).
The temple's name means 'Seitai Goji' (protect the emperor).
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更

sen.j: 熊野三山検校の地位はその後園城寺が引き継いでいたが、室町時代中期からは聖護院が務めるようになった。
sen.e: The position of Kumano Sanzan Kengyo was later passed on to Enjo-ji Temple but had been held by Shogo-in Temple since the mid Muromachi period.
The position of Kumano Sanzan Kengyo was later passed on to Enjo-ji Temple but had been held by Shogo-in Temple since the mid Muromachi period.
The position of Kumano Sanzan Kengyo was later passed on to Onjo-ji Temple but had been held by Shogo-in Temple since the mid Muromachi period.

sen.j: 1236年（嘉禎2年）、熊野に屯倉を所有していた後白河天皇の皇子の静慧法親王（じょうえほっしんのう）が入寺したことにより、熊野との結びつきを一層深めた。
sen.e: The temple's connection to Kumano deepened in 1236 when Joe Hoshinno, the son of Emperor Go-Shirakawa, who owned land in the area, served as head priest.
The temple's connection to Kumano deepened in 1236 when Joe Hoshinno, the son of Emperor Go-Shirakawa, who owned land in the area, served as head priest.
The temple's connection to Kumano deepened in 1236 when Cloistered Imperial Prince Joe, the son of Emperor Goshirakawa, who owned land in the area, served as head priest.
sen.cmt: Cloistered Imperial Prince Joe, Emperor Goshirakawaに修正

sen.j: また、静慧法親王以後、代々法親王が入寺する宮門跡寺院としての地位を固め、天台宗内で重要な地位を占めた。
sen.e: Following Joe Hoshinno, successive Hoshinno served at the temple which became established as a Miya Monzeki-ji (Imperial Priest Temple) and came to occupy an important position within the Tendai Sect.

Following Joe Hoshinno, successive Hoshinno served at the temple which became established as a Miya Monzeki-ji (Imperial Priest Temple) and came to occupy an important position within the Tendai Sect.

Following Cloistered Imperial Prince Joe, successive Cloistered Imperial Princes served at the temple which became established as a Miya Monzeki-ji (Imperial Priest Temple) and came to occupy an important position within the Tendai Sect.

sen.j: それと共に、それを背景として熊野の修験組織をまとめ上げ、熊野三山検校として修験道の重要寺院としての位置づけを確固たるものとした。
sen.e: In line with this role, the temple also consolidated the organization of Kumano's Shugendo and served an important role as Kumano Sanzan Kengyo.
In line with this role, the temple also consolidated the organization of Kumano's Shugendo and served an important role as Kumano Sanzan Kengyo.
In line with this role, the temple also consolidated the organization of Kumano's Shugendo and served an important role as Kumano Sanzan Kengyo.

sen.j: その後、応仁の乱に巻き込まれるなど、数度の火災によって焼失し、寺地も洛北（現・京都市左京区岩倉）や洛中を転々とするが、1676年（延宝4年）に現在地に再興された。
sen.e: The temple was later destroyed by fire on numerous occasions, including during the Onin War, and was relocated to northern Kyoto (present-day Iwakura, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City) and central Kyoto before being restored at its current site in 1676.

The temple was later destroyed by fire on numerous occasions, including during the Onin War, and was relocated to northern Kyoto (present-day Iwakura, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City) and central Kyoto before being restored at its current site in 1676.

The temple was later destroyed by fire on numerous occasions, including during the Onin War, and was relocated to northern Kyoto (present-day Iwakura, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City) and central Kyoto before being restored at its current site in 1676.

sen.j: 江戸時代後期には、1788年（天明8年）と1854年（安政元年）の内裏炎上に際し、光格天皇と孝明天皇が一時期仮宮として使用していたため、「聖護院旧仮皇居」として国の史跡に指定されている。
sen.e: Shogo-in Temple has been nationally designated a historic site under the name "Shogoin Kyuukarikoukyo" (lit. Shogo-in Temple Former Temporary Imperial Palace) as Emperor Kokaku and Emperor Komei temporarily used the temple as an Imperial Palace following the fires that broke out at Imperial Palace during the Edo period 1788 and 1854.

Shogo-in Temple has been nationally designated a historic site under the name "Shogoin Kyuukarikoukyo" (lit. Shogo-in Temple Former Temporary Imperial Palace) as Emperor Kokaku and Emperor Komei temporarily used the temple as an Imperial Palace following the fires that broke out at Imperial Palace during the Edo period 1788 and 1854.

Shogo-in Temple has been nationally designated a historic site under the name 'Shogoin Kyukarikokyo' (lit. Shogo-in Temple Former Temporary Imperial Palace) as Emperor Kokaku and Emperor Komei temporarily used the temple as an Imperial Palace following the fires that broke out at Imperial Palace during the Edo period 1788 and 1854.
sen.cmt: Kyuukarikoukyo→Kyukarikokyoとし、シングルクォーテーションに変更

sen.j: 1868年（明治元年）の神仏分離令に続き、1872年（明治5年）には修験道廃止令が発布されたため、天台寺門宗に所属することになったが、第二次世界大戦後の1946年（昭和21年）、修験宗を設立（本山修験宗の設立は1957年）して天台寺門宗から独立した。
sen.e: The temple came to belong to the Tendaijimon Sect as a result of the proclamation for the abolition of Shugendo in 1872 that followed the 1868 edict ordering the separation of Buddhism and Shintoism, but in 1946, after the Second World War, the Shugen Sect was established and the temple became independent of the Tendaijimon Sect.

The temple came to belong to the Tendaijimon Sect as a result of the proclamation for the abolition of Shugendo in 1872 that followed the 1868 edict ordering the separation of Buddhism and Shintoism, but in 1946, after the Second World War, the Shugen Sect was established and the temple became independent of the Tendaijimon Sect.

The temple came to belong to the Tendaijimon Sect as a result of the proclamation for the abolition of Shugendo in 1872 that followed the 1868 edict ordering the separation of Buddhism and Shintoism, but in 1946, after the Second World War, the Shugen Sect was established (the Honzan Shugen Sect was established in 1957) and the temple became independent of the Tendaijimon Sect.
sen.cmt: （本山修験宗の設立は1957年） を訳出

sen.j: 書院 - 江戸時代初期、御所より移築した建物、国の重要文化財
sen.e: Shoin (drawing room): Relocated from the Imperial Palace during the early Edo period and is a nationally designated Important Cultural Property.
Shoin (drawing room): Relocated from the Imperial Palace during the early Edo period and is a nationally designated Important Cultural Property.
Shoin (drawing room): Relocated from the Imperial Palace during the early Edo period and is a nationally designated Important Cultural Property.

sen.j: 宸殿 - 江戸時代中期
sen.e: Shinden (Emperor's residence)
Shinden (Emperor's residence)
Shinden (Emperor's residence)

sen.j: 本堂 - 江戸時代中期
sen.e: Hon-do (main hall)

sen.e: Shoin (drawing room)

sen.j: 円珍入唐求法（にっとうぐほう）目録1巻、如意輪心中心真言観1通、智証大師像造立願文（ぞうりゅうがんもん）1通（以上、智証大師像の像内納入品）

sen.e: Painting of Fukedonoyama in Yamashiro Province

tit.cmt: 複数あるため、Sitesとしました。

sen.j: 近畿三十六不動尊第十八番
sen.e: The tenth temple on the 36 temple pilgrimage of the 36 Fudo temples in the Kinki Region.
The tenth temple on the 36 temple pilgrimage of the 36 Fudo temples in the Kinki Region.
The 18th temple of the 36 Fudo Temples in the Kinki Pilgrimage.
sen.cmt: tenth→18thに訂正、 「近畿三十六不動尊」の表現を一部修正

sen.j: 役行者霊蹟札所
sen.e: Ennogyosha Reiseki fudasho (Ennogyosha-related holy place of pilgrimage)
Ennogyosha Reiseki fudasho (Ennogyosha-related holy place of pilgrimage)
EN no Gyoja Reiseki fudasho (EN no Gyoja-related holy place of pilgrimage)
sen.cmt: 「役行者（えんのぎょうじゃ）」は人物名 (役小角の別名) のため、EN no Gyojaとしました。

sen.j: 1月 - 茶道速水流による初釜
sen.e: January: Hatsugama (the first tea ceremony of New Year) held by the Hayami-ryu School.
January: Hatsugama (the first tea ceremony of New Year) held by the Hayami-ryu School.
January: Hatsugama (the first tea ceremony of New Year) held by the Hayami-ryu School.

sen.j: 8月 - 熊野への大峰入りのために山伏が当寺に集結し、熊野へ向かう。
sen.e: August: Mountain monks assemble at the temple and depart for the "Omine-iri" pilgrimage to Kumano.
August: Mountain monks assemble at the temple and depart for the "Omine-iri" pilgrimage to Kumano.
August: Mountain monks assemble at the temple and depart for the "Omine-iri" pilgrimage to Kumano.

sen.j: 左京区聖護院地区は、和菓子の聖護院八ツ橋や、京野菜の聖護院大根・聖護院かぶ・聖護院きゅうり発祥の地。
sen.e: The Shogo-in district in Sakyo Ward is where the wagashi (traditional Japanese confectionery) "Shogoin Yatsuhashi" and the dishes "Shogoin Daikon" (daikon radish), "Shogoin Kabu" (turnip) and "Shogoin Kyuri" (cucumber) originated.

The Shogo-in district in Sakyo Ward is where the wagashi (traditional Japanese confectionery) "Shogoin Yatsuhashi" and the dishes "Shogoin Daikon" (daikon radish), "Shogoin Kabu" (turnip) and "Shogoin Kyuri" (cucumber) originated.

The Shogo-in district in Sakyo Ward is where the wagashi (traditional Japanese confectionery) "Shogoin Yatsuhashi" and the dishes "Shogoin Daikon" (daikon radish), "Shogoin Kabu" (turnip) and "Shogoin Kyuri" (cucumber) originated.

sen.j: なお、聖護院きゅうりは現存しないので注意。
sen.e: However Shogoin Kyuri no longer exists.
However Shogoin Kyuri no longer exists.
However Shogoin Kyuri no longer exists.

sen.j: 聖護院節成胡瓜という別種のきゅうりは現存するが、これは聖護院とは何ら関係ない。
sen.e: Another cucumber dish known as "Shogoin Fushinari" is still made but is unrelated to Shogo-in Temple.
Another cucumber dish known as "Shogoin Fushinari" is still made but is unrelated to Shogo-in Temple.
Another cucumber dish known as "Shogoin Fushinari" is still made but is unrelated to Shogo-in Temple.

sen.e: Take the Keihan Electric Railway Keihan Oto Line to Marutamachi Station and walk for 7 minutes.
Take the Keihan Electric Railway Keihan Oto Line to Marutamachi Station and walk for 7 minutes.
